doc.ContractDescription: LEVERAGING HIGH RESOLUTION SPECTRA TO UNDERSTAND THE DISK AND RELATIVISTIC IRON LINE OF CYGNUS X-1 THERE IS CURRENTLY SIGNIFICANT DEBATE AS TO THE PHYSICAL MECHANISMS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE CONTINUUM OF X-RAY SPECTRALLY ``HARD STATES'' OF BLACK HOLE CANDIDATES (BHC) ACCRETING IN BINARIES. THIS DEBATE RANGES FROM THE BROADER ISSUE OF WHETHER OR NOT THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE X-RAY BAND FROM AN OUTFLOW OR JET, TO MORE NARROWLY FOCUSED ISSUES WITHIN GIVEN CLASSES OF MODELS. THE HARD X-RAY EMISSION HAS TRADITIONALLY BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO A COMPTONIZING THERMAL CORONA, WHERE THE CORONA LIES CENTRAL TO A TRUNCATED OUTER THIN DISK. HOWEVER, IF THE CORONA IS DRIVEN OUTWARDS BY RADIATIVE PRESSURE COULD IT INSTEAD OVERLAY THE INNER DISK? CAN THE OPTICALLY THICK, GEOMETRICALLY THIN DISK EXTEND INWARD NEARLY TO THE INNERMOST STABLE CIRCULAR ORBIT? AT THE VERY LEAST, DOES THE DISK EXTEND DEEP ENOUGH INTO THE POTENTIAL WELL SUCH THAT STUDY OF THE RELATIVISTICALLY BROADENED FLUORESCENCE LINE YIELDS A MEASUREMENT OF THE BLACK HOLE SPIN? OBSERVATIONS OF THE BRIGHT, PERSISTENTLY EMITTING BHC CYGNUS X-1 HAVE PLAYED A CENTRAL ROLE IN THESE DEBATES. THE MAJORITY OF THE OBSERVATIONS OF CYG X-1, HOWEVER, HAVE BEEN PERFORMED WITH THE ROSSI X-RAY TIMING EXPLORER (RXTE). AS THE DISK SPECTRUM PEAKS AT ENERGIES 1 KEV, RXTE DOES NOT DIRECTLY MEASURE THE DISK COMPONENT. FURTHERMORE, RXTE LACKS THE SPECTRAL RESOLUTION TO DESCRIBE THE DETAILS OF THE BROADENED FE LINE WELL-ENOUGH TO ATTEMPT A LINE-BASED SPIN MEASUREMENT. CHANDRA, XMM-NEWTON, AND SUZAKU SPECTRA, ON THE OTHER HAND, ALL HAVE BOTH LOW ENERGY COVERAGE AND MODERATE-TO-HIGH SPECTRAL RESOLUTION IN THE FE BAND. THE LATTER TWO INSTRUMENTS ARE ESPECIALLY WELL-SUITED FOR MEASUREMENTS OF THE DISK AND FE LINE REGION. CHANDRA OBSERVATIONS, HOWEVER, POINT OUT TWO DETAILS OFTEN IGNORED IN CCD STUDIES OF CYG X-1: THE IONIZED WIND OF THE SECONDARY, AND THE DUST SCATTERING HALO. THE LATTER WILL ALWAYS AFFECT DISK CONTINUUM MEASUREMENTS WITH XMM-NEWTON, AND WILL AFFECT DISK CONTINUUM MEASUREMENTS WITH SUZAKU IF SPECTRAL VARIABILITY HAS OCCURRED WITHIN A FEW TENS OF THOUSANDS OF SECONDS PRIOR TO THE OBSERVATION. THE IONIZED WIND (AND THE ASSOCIATED COLD, OPTICALLY THICK ``ACCRETION DIPS'' THAT PREFERENTIALLY OCCUR NEAR ORBITAL PHASE ZERO, I.E., SUPERIOR CONJUNCTION) AFFECT BOTH THE DISK CONTINUUM MEASUREMENTS AND THE FE BAND. WE HAVE RECENTLY COMPLETED CHANDRA STUDIES OF BOTH THE DUST HALO AND THE ORBITAL PHASE-DEPENDENT IONIZED WIND IN CYG X-1. WE PROPOSE TO USE THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THESE STUDIES TO MORE CAREFULLY EXAMINE THREE DATASETS: 1) A SET OF SUZAKU OBSERVATIONS, WHICH WE WILL USE TO EXAMINE THE DISK AND FE LINE REGION OF CYG X-1, 2) A MULTI-SATELLITE SIMULTANEOUS OBSERVATION OF CYG X-1 WHICH WE WILL USE TO EXAMINE THE EFFECT AND APPEARANCE OF BOTH THE DUST HALO AND IONIZED WIND IN EACH X-RAY DETECTOR, AS WELL AS TO EXAMINE THE (BRIGHT SOURCE) CROSS-CALIBRATION AMONG X-RAY DETECTORS, AND 3) A SET OF XMM-NEWTON OBSERVATIONS WHICH WE WILL SPECIFICALLY COMPARE TO THE SUZAKU CCD SPECTRA TO DETERMINE IF ONE CAN DESCRIBE THE FE LINE SPECTRUM WITH A SET OF MODELS THAT SHARE A COMMON BLACK HOLE SPIN.

doc.ContractDescription: PLANETARY WAVES ARE HIGHLY IMPORTANT FOR THE MARTIAN ATMOSPHERE. THEY PRODUCE SUBSTANTIAL HEAT AND MOMENTUM FLUXES THAT STRONGLY INFLUENCE ATMOSPHERIC STRUCTURE, CIRCULATION, AND THE ASSOCIATED WEATHER AND CLIMATE. IN ADDITION,THEY INFLUENCE THE TRANSPORT AND DISTRIBUTION OF WATER VAPOR, DUST AND OTHER TRACERS. OBSERVATIONS SHOW THAT LARGE-SCALE EDDIES IN THE 20 KM<Z<80 KM ALTITUDE RANGE ARE DOMINATED BY SMALL ZONAL WAVENUMBERS (K = 1 AND 2). THIS PROPOSAL WILL INVESTIGATE THE CHARACTERISTICS AND EFFECTS OF LARGE-SCALE PLANETARY WAVES WITH ZONAL WAVENUMBER K = 1 AND 2 IN THE MIDDLE ATMOSPHERE OF MARS. THESE WAVES INCLUDE MIGRATING AND NON-MIGRATING THERMAL TIDES, (QUASI-) STATIONARY WAVES AND EASTWARD / WESTWARD TRAVELING WAVES. WE WILL STUDY THEIR (A) MODE AND STRUCTURE, (B) SEASONALITY AND VARIABILITY, (C) PROPAGATION AND ENERGETICS, AND (D) INTERACTION AND EFFECT. WE WILL CONCENTRATE ON THE "DUST STORM SEASON" (LS = 180 - 360) SINCE THIS SEASON EXHIBITS THE LARGEST VARIABILITY. THIS STUDY WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING SCIENCE QUESTIONS. 1) WHAT CONTROLS / MODULATES ABRUPT / GRADUAL WAVE MODE TRANSITION? 2) WHAT IS THE NATURE OF TROPICAL - EXTRATROPICAL COUPLING? 3) WHAT ARE THE EFFECTS OF INTERACTIONS OF THESE WAVES WITH THE MEAN FLOW AND WITH EACH OTHER IN THE GENERALCIRCULATION? 4) HOW DO THEY CHANGE UNDER VARIOUS DUST SCENARIOS? THESE INTER-RELATED SCIENCE QUESTIONS ARE MOTIVATED BY NEW BEHAVIORS OF LARGE-SCALE WAVES REVEALED BY RECENT SPACECRAFT OBSERVATIONS. THEY ARE CRUCIAL FOR REVEALING THE PROPERTY AND ROLE OF LARGE-SCALE WAVES IN THE MIDDLE ATMOSPHERE OF MARS, AND WILL LEAD TO BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE MARTIAN ATMOSPHERIC GENERAL CIRCULATION. THE ANALYSES (A) - (D) WORK TOGETHER TO ADDRESS THE SCIENCE QUESTIONS 1)-4). THIS PROPOSAL ADVANCES THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE MARTIAN ATMOSPHERE BY ANSWERING FUNDAMENTAL SCIENCE QUESTIONS PROMPTED BY RECENT SPACECRAFT OBSERVATIONS. IT DOES NOT DIRECTLY ANALYZE MARS SPACECRAFT DATA. INSTEAD, IT SEEKS THE UNDERLYING MECHANISMS THOUGH ANALYSES OF SIMULATION RESULTS THAT EXHIBIT THE SAME QUALITATIVE BEHAVIOR AS THE DATA AND HAVE THE ADVANTAGE OF AVAILABILITY OF THE FULL SET OF REGULAR GRIDDED VARIABLES. THIS PROPOSAL FITS THE SCOPE OF THE MARS FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH PROGRAM, AND IS RELEVANT TO MARS SCIENTIFIC GOALS, OBJECTIVES, INVESTIGATIONS AND PRIORITIES AS SUMMARIZED BY MEPAG (2012) - GOAL II OBJECTIVE A.
doc.MajorAgency: LARGE-SCALE WAVES IN THE MIDDLE ATMOSPHERE OF MARS
